update.description:
Pull request #17 added an example on how to override the default style using cmake. This PR adds many other ways to do it:

From the command line:

    ign gui -s libPublisher.so -t examples/standalone/style_cmake/style.qss

On a config file:

    ign gui -c examples/config/stylesheet.config

With C++:

    ignition::gui::setQssFile(const std::string &_qssFile)
    ignition::gui::applyStyleSheet()

Through the GUI:

![qss.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/4084367144-qss.gif)

## Future work

* Allow separate stylesheets for each plugin
* Offer preset material design styles. For this I'm currently pursuing 2 leads:
    1. Generating stylesheets substituting color variables on a template stylesheet
    1. Supporting QtQuick and its built-in material design styles
update.title: Custom stylesheets

content.raw:
You could change the test to be:

1. Start of test, get and store the default color.
2. Change stylesheet.
3. Set style back to default, and compare result with the default color from step 1.
content.html:
You could change the test to be:

  1. Start of test, get and store the default color.
  2. Change stylesheet.
  3. Set style back to default, and compare result with the default color from step 1.

content.html: Ahh yeah this might be OS-dependant, since it's testing Qt's native color. Nice catch, I'll change the test.

content.raw:
It's a nice thing to support tests without installing. For example, installing may pollute my computer with a version of code that I don't want. However, I still want to review a pull request.

I think you can accomplish this with clever usage of path information. Gazebo's tests of its command line tools might be a place to look for an example.
content.html:
It's a nice thing to support tests without installing. For example, installing may pollute my computer with a version of code that I don't want. However, I still want to review a pull request.

I think you can accomplish this with clever usage of path information. Gazebo's tests of its command line tools might be a place to look for an example.

content.raw: I looked a bit into detecting malformed stylesheets and didn't find any Qt API for that. They print an error, I suppose we can try to catch that. I was wondering if there was an  alternative, like checking for a valid CSS structure.
content.html: I looked a bit into detecting malformed stylesheets and didn't find any Qt API for that. They print an error, I suppose we can try to catch that. I was wondering if there was an alternative, like checking for a valid CSS structure.

content.raw: Yeah they require install. Is there a way to test the command line tool without installing? Is installing before tests a bad thing?
content.html: Yeah they require install. Is there a way to test the command line tool without installing? Is installing before tests a bad thing?

content.raw: When  I use the GUI to set a stylesheet, and choose a bad stylesheet then the style changes to a default configuration. Is it possible to keep the existing style when a bad stylesheet is attempted?
content.html: When I use the GUI to set a stylesheet, and choose a bad stylesheet then the style changes to a default configuration. Is it possible to keep the existing style when a bad stylesheet is attempted?

content.raw: Also, I think tests require `make install`. This can be handled in a separate PR.
content.html: Also, I think tests require make install. This can be handled in a separate PR.

content.raw:
Do you see this test failure?

```
/data/ignition/ign-gui/src/Iface_TEST.cc:265: Failure

Expected: bg.name()
Which is: { 2-byte object <23-00>, 2-byte object <65-00>, 2-byte object <66-00>, 2-byte object <65-00>, 2-byte object <62-00>, 2-byte object <65-00>, 2-byte object <37-00> }
#efebe7
```

content.raw: I'm going to refactor this a bit.
content.html: I'm going to refactor this a bit.

content.raw:
Done: fc560e0

I also looked a bit into detecting whether the stylesheet is malformed, but it seems there isn't a trivial way to catch that, so for now we can count on the error message printed by Qt: `Could not parse application stylesheet`.
content.html:
Done: fc560e0

I also looked a bit into detecting whether the stylesheet is malformed, but it seems there isn't a trivial way to catch that, so for now we can count on the error message printed by Qt: Could not parse application stylesheet.

content.html:

Side question. Is set only needed for the command line arguments?

Yeah. I was thinking "Failed to open" was to vague. How about this:

if (!file.open(QFile::ReadOnly)) { if (_qssFile.empty()) ignerr << "Empty filename message" else if (!file.exists()) ignerr << "file doesn't exist message" else ignerr << "Failed to open [" << _qssFile << "]. Potentially invalid permissions" << std::endl; return false; }

content.raw: I think the `file.open` call below is performing these checks. There's already a test for loading an empty string. Is the comment about adding separate error messages for empty string, in-existent file and corrupt file?

content.raw:
Is this the desired behaviour:

* `set` -> `apply(void)`: applies the file previously set
* `set` -> `apply(file)`: applies file, forgets previously set
* `apply(void)`: applies default file
* `apply(file)`: applies file
content.html:
Is this the desired behaviour:

  • set -> apply(void): applies the file previously set
  • set -> apply(file): applies file, forgets previously set
  • apply(void): applies default file
  • apply(file): applies file

content.raw:
You're right about `ignlog`.

I played a bit with the log level in c214713. Some example outputs:

~~~
$ ign gui -s Publisher -v 4
[Msg] Loading standalone plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:245] Init app
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:563] Run dialogs
[GUI] [Msg] Setting QSS file [:/style.qss]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:375] Applying stylesheet
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:587] Showing dialog [Publisher]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:218] Dialog [Publisher] closed.
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:259] Stop

$ ign gui -s Publisher -v 3
[Msg] Loading standalone plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Msg] Setting QSS file [:/style.qss]

$ ign gui -c examples/config/pubsub.config -v 4
[Msg] Loading config file [examples/config/pubsub.config]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:245] Init app
[GUI] [Msg] Loading config [examples/config/pubsub.config]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [libPublisher.so]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [libTopicEcho.so]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:458] Create main window
[GUI] [Msg] Added plugin [Publisher] to main window
[GUI] [Msg] Added plugin [Topic echo] to main window
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:503] Applying config
[GUI] [Msg] Setting QSS file [:/style.qss]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:375] Applying stylesheet
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:545] Run main window
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:375] Applying stylesheet
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:259] Stop

$ ign gui -c examples/config/pubsub.config -v 3
[Msg] Loading config file [examples/config/pubsub.config]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading config [examples/config/pubsub.config]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [libPublisher.so]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [libTopicEcho.so]
[GUI] [Msg] Added plugin [Publisher] to main window
[GUI] [Msg] Added plugin [Topic echo] to main window
[GUI] [Msg] Setting QSS file [:/style.qss]
~~~

You're right about ignlog.

[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:587] Showing dialog [Publisher]
[GUI] [Dbg] [Iface.cc:218] Dialog [Publisher] closed.

$ ign gui -s Publisher -v 3
[Msg] Loading standalone plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Msg] Loading plugin [Publisher]
[GUI] [Msg] Setting QSS file [:/style.qss]
